channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Time is short to evacuate for Hurricane Milton. And, EPA mandates lead pipe removal
item.description: Hurricane Milton is expected to make landfall in Florida late tonight as a dangerous storm, and time is running out for people to evacuate. And, the EPA has mandated a nationwide lead pipe removal.
item.content:encoded:
Hurricane Milton is expected to make landfall in Florida late tonight as a dangerous storm, and time is running out for people to evacuate. And, the EPA has mandated a nationwide lead pipe removal.

(Image credit: Chandan Khanna)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Researchers work to make pitch-perfect turf for the 2026 World Cup
item.description: Researchers work to grow grass that will offer the same level playing field for athletes at the various soccer venues that will be used during the 2026 FIFA World Cup
item.content:encoded:
Researchers work to grow grass that will offer the same level playing field for athletes at the various soccer venues that will be used during the 2026 FIFA World Cup

(Image credit: Sophia Saliby)
item.dc:creator: Sophia Saliby

item.title: Nobel Prize in chemistry awarded to scientists for work on proteins
item.description: The Nobel Prize in chemistry was awarded Wednesday to David Baker, Demis Hassabis and John Jumper for their work with proteins. The awards continue with the literature prize on Thursday.
item.content:encoded:
The Nobel Prize in chemistry was awarded Wednesday to David Baker, Demis Hassabis and John Jumper for their work with proteins. The awards continue with the literature prize on Thursday.

(Image credit: Jeff Chiu)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Only 2% of charitable giving goes to women. Can Melinda French Gates change that?
item.description: The philanthropist is spending $1 billion — and leveraging her ever-growing celebrity — to call more attention to the systemic problems facing women and girls. Now she's focusing even more on women's health.
item.content:encoded:
The philanthropist is spending $1 billion — and leveraging her ever-growing celebrity — to call more attention to the systemic problems facing women and girls. Now she's focusing even more on women's health.

(Image credit: LUDOVIC MARIN)
item.dc:creator: Maria Aspan

item.title: They came to Asheville looking for a 'climate haven.' Then came Hurricane Helene
item.description: When Mary Ann Roser and her husband moved to Asheville four months ago they introduced themselves to neighbors as “climate refugees from Austin.” After Helene, she has thoughts on “climate havens."
item.content:encoded:
When Mary Ann Roser and her husband moved to Asheville four months ago they introduced themselves to neighbors as “climate refugees from Austin.” After Helene, she has thoughts on “climate havens."

(Image credit: Sean Rayford)
item.dc:creator: Julia Simon

item.title: Evacuation windows narrow as Hurricane Milton approaches Florida
item.description: The National Hurricane Center predicts the storm surge could get as high as 15 feet in some places, and rainfall totals could reach 18 inches.
item.content:encoded:
The National Hurricane Center predicts the storm surge could get as high as 15 feet in some places, and rainfall totals could reach 18 inches.

(Image credit: Mike Carlson)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: Many people in jail have the right to vote. So do many felons
item.description: People who are in jail and haven't been convicted of a crime — and even many who have been convicted — retain their right to vote. But it's often challenging for them to exercise it.
item.content:encoded:
People who are in jail and haven't been convicted of a crime — and even many who have been convicted — retain their right to vote. But it's often challenging for them to exercise it.

(Image credit: Charlie Riedel)
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: In battleground states, it's not just about winning — but also losing by less
item.description: In a state where every vote matters, both Democratic and Republican campaigns are not only trying to win in counties where they’re strongest, they’re also trying to lose by less.
item.content:encoded:
In a state where every vote matters, both Democratic and Republican campaigns are not only trying to win in counties where they’re strongest, they’re also trying to lose by less.

(Image credit: Keren Carrión)
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: True crime drama at Supreme Court pits Oklahoma against its top criminal court
item.description: Richard Glossip has had nine execution dates set over the years. He's eaten his last meal three times. He was tried twice and has had multiple appeals, including one at the Supreme Court.
item.content:encoded:
Richard Glossip has had nine execution dates set over the years. He's eaten his last meal three times. He was tried twice and has had multiple appeals, including one at the Supreme Court.

(Image credit: Larry French)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: In a rematch, mama bear Grazer defeats rival that killed her cub to win Fat Bear Week
item.description: The annual Fat Bear Week honors bears that have sufficiently bulked up in the months before entering hibernation.
item.content:encoded:
The annual Fat Bear Week honors bears that have sufficiently bulked up in the months before entering hibernation.

(Image credit: F. Jimenez/AP)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie
